q3.value:
The role of personality in authoritarianism has long been an area of interest. Perry & Sibley (2011) use a panel study to find that low agreeableness correlates with SDO (low agreeableness, higher SDO), while Openness to Experience correlates negatively with RWA (high Openness to Experience, low RWA). Nicol and De France (2016) show that Openness and Conscientiousness predict RWA, while Openness and Agreeableness predict SDO. 

Stenner and Feldman developed a model, detailed in Karen Stenner's 2005 book (The Authortiarian Dynamic) which suggests that manifest authoritarianism is the result of authoritarian predisposition (as measured by child-rearing values) and normative threat (a threat to the unity or cohesion of a group). This model suggests, therefore, that normative threat moderates the relationship between authoritarian disposition & views. 

We assess the role of the Big 5 personality dimensions in moderating this relationship. Rather than correlating Big 5 dimensions with authoritarianism outright, as others have done before us, we seek instead to see if people of a certain personality type are more likely to have a stronger or weaker relationship between their authoritarian disposition and their manifest authoritarianism.

q4.value:
Null hypothesis: The relationship between authoritarian predisposition (measured by child-rearing attitudes) and manifest authoritarianism (measured by RWA & SDO) will be the same regardless of all personality dimensions.

Alternative hypothesis: The relationship between authoritarian disposition and manifest authoritarianism will be different based on scores of at least one Big 5 personality dimension.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is an observational study. We will observe the efficacy of the Big 5 personality dimensions as moderators of the relationship between child rearing attitudes and manifest authoritarian attitudes.

q9.value: The subjects will be randomly assigned into one of two equally-signed conditions using Quadratics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon MTurk. Participants will be compensated $0.1 for their involvement. Participants must be at least 18 years old, be located in the U.S., have HIT approval ratings higher than 95%, and have more than 5,000 HITS approved. The participants will not have participated  in our pilot or other pertinent studies. If sufficient participants are not recruited within a few days, the pay may be raised, and the latter two (HIT-related) constraints may be lowered.

q14.value: Based on a pilot we ran, the effect size seems relatively small, and 350 participants is an adequate balance of a sample size and economic considerations.

q15.value: We will try to collect 350 samples; if more are accidentally collected prior to any analysis, we will keep them.

question.value:
Social Dominance Orientation Scale: An eight-item shortened scale from Sidanius et al. (2015).

Right-Wing Authoritarianism Scale: A six-item shortened scale from Bizumic and Duckitt (2018), called Very Short Authoritarianism scale.

Child-Rearing Scale: A four-question scale similar to the scale used in the ANES.

Big 5 Personality scale: A 30-item scale adapted from Soto & John (2017)

Works Cited 

Ho, A. K., Sidanius, J., Kteily, N., Sheehy-Skeffington, J, Pratto, F., Henkel, K. E., Foels, R.,
and Stewart, A. L. (2015). The nature of social dominance orientation: Theorizing and
measuring preferences for intergroup inequality using the new SDO7 scale. Journal of
Personality and Social Psychology, 109(6), 1003-1028.

Bizumic, B., Duckitt, J. (2018). Investigating Right Wing Authoritarianism With a Very Short Authoritarianism Scale. Journal of Social and Political Psychology, 6(1), 129–150.

Soto, C., John, O. (2017). Short and extra-short forms of the Big Five Inventory-2: The BFI-2-S and BFI-2-XS. Journal of Research in Personality, 68, 69-81.

Binary split of each Big 5 personality dimension to graph relationship between child-rearing and SDO/RWA with each personality dimension at different percentiles (e.g., lower 50% conscientiousness vs higher 50% conscientiousness)
Fisher's R-to-Z transformation to test significance of binary split.
We may use plots to visualize some of this data.
Regressions of RWA/SDO as dependent variables, Big 5 personality & child-rearing as independent variables

q20.value:
SDO, RWA, and the Big 5 personality dimensions are measured as the sum of the responses to individual questions that compose them. 

The traditional child-rearing scale is a binary scale, where people select there view of whether one or another trait is more important for children to have. We aimed to make a more sensitive scale, so our measure of child-rearing attitudes is a six-point Likert scale; otherwise, the scale is identical to the child-rearing scales used elsewhere. We may collapse the six-point scale to a binary scale, should reviewers request that we adjust the data to reflect how it is commonly collected.

q21.value: We will use the standard p=.05 criteria for determining statistical significance. We will use a two-tailed test in our analyses.

q22.value: We will exclude data if 1) the subject fails our initial test of competence, which prevents the subject from participating in the study; or 2) the subject has universally, without discriminating between questions whatsoever selected the same answer choice (e.g., the top or bottom choice throughout). The initial tests of competence includes a captcha verification box, a prompt to select the most accurate statement, with the options being: "I am @ rabbit", "I am @ lion", and "I am @ human" in legible hand-writing, and a short blurb with a question that tests comprehension. These questions are intended to screen for bots and people who don't adequately speak English.

q23.value: Most of the data we request, the subjects are required to submit. We will keep all submissions (subject to the exclusion criteria) who respond to SDO, RWA, child-rearing attitudes, and the big five scale, regardless of whether political opinions and demographic information. We will not keep all participants who fail to respond to SDO, RWA, child-rearing attitudes, or the big five scale.

q25.value: We expect a relatively small effect size, but believe that, should we find that big five personality dimensions are real moderators of the relationship between child-rearing and authoritarian attitudes, this is an interesting and important fact.

We assess the role of the Big 5 personality dimensions in moderating this relationship. Rather than correlating Big 5 dimensions with authoritarianism outright, as others have done before us, we seek instead to see if people of a certain personality type are more likely to have a stronger or weaker relationship between their authoritarian disposition and their manifest authoritarianism.

attributes.title: Can LEGO Predict Couples' Closeness and Relationship Behaviors Over Time?
attributes.description: This registration involves the preregistration of new study hypotheses to be tested using data from parent project DRRAW I (see osf.io/ekv6x).

summary.value: Contained in this registration is the document detailing the present research question, hypotheses, and analytic plan.

registration_responses.summary: Contained in this registration is the document detailing the present research question, hypotheses, and analytic plan.

attributes.title: Perceived Behavioural Control and Climate Change

q1.value: Perceived Behavioural Control: Motivating Collective Action in Climate Change

q3.value: Though there is strong evidence to suggest that Perceived behavioural control affects pro-environmental intention, there has not yet been any attempt to establish whether these intentions are translated into actual behaviour. This project aims to test whether a causal relationship exists between perceived behavioural control and behaviour change. The study will involve a 3 wave longitudinal design using online questionnaires. We plan to manipulate perceived behavioural control using so-called "recall and writing tasks", and track the effect of this manipulation on meat consumption.

q4.value:
H1: Increasing participants' perceived behavioural control (operationalized as self-efficacy) will lead to greater change in pro-environmental intention (operationalized as reported likelihood of reducing consumption of beef and lamb in the future) than is found in control groups who have not had efficacy beliefs enhanced.

H2: Increasing participants' perceived behavioural control will lead to greater change in pro-environmental behaviour (operationalized as reduced beef and lamb consumption) than control groups who have not had efficacy beliefs enhanced.

H3: Increasing participants' perceived behavioural control will lead to greater change in a secondary pro-environmental behaviour (operationalized as signing up to receive pro-environmental information via email) than control groups who have not had efficacy beliefs enhanced.

H4: SES and environmental beliefs will moderate the relationship between the efficacy manipulation and intention and behaviour.

H5: Any increase or decrease in pro-environmental behaviour will be accompanied by a corresponding increase or decrease in perceived behavioural control

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This study will utilise a 3-wave longitudinal design. The first wave will be used to record the participants’ pre-existing “perceived behavioural control” as well as their socioeconomic status. SES is being measured because previous research has found it to moderate the relationship between sense of control and pro-environmental behaviour. Perceived behavioural control will be measured at all 3 time points: first to ensure that our manipulation actually affects perceived behavioural control, and second to see whether any change in behaviour is linked to a similar change in behavioural control. Participants will then be asked to track their meat consumption over the next week. 

The second wave of the study will involve splitting the participants into a control group and an experimental group. Both groups will be asked how much meat they consumed in the past week. The experimental group will then be asked to complete a writing task involving discussing a time in the past when they felt in control, while the control group are asked to write about a time that was important in their lives. Both will then be asked to read a persuasive text arguing for reducing consumption of beef and lamb. At this point we will measure pro-environmental beliefs, so that we can later test whether perceived behavioural control predicts behaviour over and above beliefs. This was also included due to its pre-established relationship with both SES and perceived behavioural control. Participants will then have their intention to act recorded, before having their perceived behavioural control recorded once again and being asked to record their meat consumption for another week.

Wave 3 will consist of a question about how much meat participants ate in the past week as well as a final perceived behavioural control measurement. There will also be a second behavioural measure, which is designed to be a smaller commitment than the main dependent variable. This will involve asking participants they wish to sign up to receive emails containing further pro-environmental information. Participants will then be debriefed.

q9.value: We will (simply) randomly assign participants to each condition, ensuring that an equal proportion are assigned to each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the online service Prolific. We will target participants between the ages of 18 and 35 who have pro-environmental views, and who are not already vegetarian or vegan. Participants will also be from the UK. Participants will be paid minimum wage. We chose to limit our analysis to an age range of individuals for several reasons. The sample demographic on the prolific website is heavily skewed to this age range, so limiting it as such should not affect our sample size. As our sample size is fairly small, we decided that it was better to avoid the chance of the few particularly old or young participants being randomly assigned more to one condition than another and thus skewing our results. We deemed it worth the slight impact on the generalisability of our results. 

We selected only participants from the UK to protect against potential cultural differences.

We will also measure the time taken to leave the page of the persuasive text. Given the text is over 400 words long, if participants click away from the page in less than 20 seconds their data shall be excluded, with the assumption that they have not read the text.

Participants who do not complete all 3 waves will be excluded from those analyses which require their participation in all waves.

Given that several of our analyses are sensitive to outliers, we will be excluding participants who fall outside of 3 standard deviations from the mean.

There are several attention checks throughout the experiment. Participants who fail these will be excluded. 

Once data is collected, 2 researchers will conduct a double-blind analysis. The researchers will code each of the short stories, assigning them to either the “efficacy” or “control” condition. Any stories which either: researchers disagree on, or: the agreed upon label does not match their actual condition, will be excluded from the primary analysis. The full dataset will be used for a secondary analysis which aims to determine whether prior studies which did not use this manipulation check may have introduced confounds to their results. Any significant effects found in this secondary analysis will not be considered except in comparison with the main analysis.

q13.value: We will recruit 150 participants in Wave 1. These will be split into 2 groups of 75, which will be taken forward (allowing for attrition)  into Wave 3.

q14.value:
Sample size will be determined by financial constraints. The study has £300 to spend on research, which will be divided among participants, with the price per participant determined by the length of the overall questionnaire. Time taken was calculated ahead of time using a pilot study in which convenience sampling was used (from which data was not collected).

We completed a power calculation which suggested that we needed at least 17 pairs of participants per condition. We then calculated expected attrition based on prior similar studies, and found that most had around a 35% attrition rate. Accounting for attrition, we needed at least 52 participants per condition. Our funding allows for a larger sample than this, so the only limit was financial constraints.

We also ran a full simulation of the study with generated data, and calculated that we had the power to identify moderate to small effects if they existed with our current sample size, even with predicted attrition.

question.value: The independent variable will be random assignment to either the experimental or control condition. Participants in the experimental condition will be asked to write around 100 words about a time in the past when they felt they were in control. Participants in the control condition will be asked to write around 100 words about an important time in their past.

This study has 3 dependent variables.
The first dependent variable is intention to reduce consumption of beef and lamb in the future. This will be measured using a 1-7 Likert Scale.

The second dependent variable is meat consumption (specifically beef and lamb) in a period of 1 week. We will ask participants to report how many times they have eaten each type of meat, from a list of: Beef, Lamb, Poultry, Pork, Fish, Other.

A third dependent variable will be willingness to receive emails about pro-environmental topics. This will be operationalized using an optional sign up sheet within the questionnaire. 

We will also measure perceived behavioural control (PBC), Socioeconomic status (SES) and pro-environmental beliefs.

Our 2 SES questions will be averaged and then standardized (z-scored).

All PBC questions will be recoded to ensure that high responses equate to high PBC, and averaged in wave.

We will aggregate beef and lamb consumption.

We will use a one way ANOVA to investigate the impact of the experimental condition on pro-environmental intention.

In order to test our second hypothesis, a Mixed ANOVA will be used to compare the differences between the two groups at different time points. We will use the Mixed ANOVA to compare the consumption of beef and lamb at week 1 (before the intervention), with the consumption of beef and lamb at week 2 (after the intervention). 

In order to test hypothesis 3, we will use chi squared tests to compare the mean difference in willingness to receive information between the two conditions.

We will run a number of regressions in order to test hypotheses 4 and 5. In order to determine whether SES, environmental beliefs or PBC moderated the relationship between the efficacy manipulation and intention/behaviour, we will use 3 different statistical tests. We shall use a binomial logistic regression to investigate this hypothesis with our secondary dependent variable (willingness to receive information). We will use an ordinal logistic regression when investigating the relationship with intention, and we will use multiple regression to investigate the effect on our main dependent variable (beef and lamb consumption). Hierarchical linear regressions will be used to establish whether our predictor variables predict over each other (for example, whether an interaction between PBC and environmental beliefs predicts over environmental beliefs). We shall also run a mediated moderation analysis followed by a path analysis to attempt to determine the relationship between SES, environmental beliefs and PBC, and how each relate to intention and behaviour. We will investigate the interaction between SES and condition, Environmental beliefs and SES, Perceived behavioural control and SES, and Environmental beliefs and perceived behavioural control. These interaction effects are based on relationships discovered by past research, such as Eom, Kim and Sherman (2018).

In order to test our fifth hypothesis, we will also be measuring perceived behavioural control over the 3 waves of our study: First to ensure that our manipulation actually affects perceived behavioural control, and second to see whether any change in behaviour is linked to a similar change in behavioural control. We will use a one way repeated measures ANOVA to track the change in PBC over time in our two groups.

A secondary part of our analysis centres around a test of methodology. We will run one analysis using our entire dataset, and a second analysis using only data from participants who have correctly completed the writing task. This analysis will reveal whether the findings of previous studies which have not conducted this manipulation check may have been compromised.
To achieve this aim, 2 researchers will conduct a double-blind analysis of the passages. The researchers will code each of the short stories, assigning them to either the “efficacy” or “important” condition. Only those stories which both researchers agree are stories which show efficacy, and which were written by participants in the efficacy condition, will be included in the primary analysis as experimental participants (and vice versa for controls). By doing this, we also ensure that only those participants who properly experienced the experimental manipulation are included in the main analysis.

q20.value:
Likert scale responses will be recoded into numbers, with high responses equating to greater agreement. 

Condition will be recoded into a numerical representation of the categories: Experimental will become "1", Control will become "0"

Multi-question scales (for Measuring pro-environmental beliefs and perceived behavioural control) will be recoded so that high responses always equal greater agreement (More control or more pro-environmental beliefs)

q21.value:
We will be using the standard significance value of p<0.05

We will Bonferroni correct for post-hoc tests (such as the post-hoc test for our Mixed ANOVA) but we do not believe that such corrections are necessary elsewhere. Our 3 dependent variables are measuring different behaviours, and we will only consider findings taken from the post-manipulation check dataset to confirm our second hypothesis.

q22.value:
We will measure the time taken to leave the page of the persuasive text. Given the text is over 400 words long, if participants click away from the page in less than 20 seconds their data shall be excluded, with the assumption that they have not read the text.

Participants who do not complete all 3 waves will be excluded from those analyses which require their participation in all waves.

Given that several of our analyses are sensitive to outliers, we will be excluding participants who fall outside of 3 standard deviations from the mean.

There are several attention checks throughout the experiment. Participants who fail these will be excluded. 

Once data is collected, 2 researchers will conduct a double-blind analysis. The researchers will code each of the short stories, assigning them to either the “efficacy” or “control” condition. Any stories which either: researchers disagree on, or: the agreed upon label does not match their actual condition, will be excluded from the primary analysis. The full dataset will be used for a secondary analysis which aims to determine whether prior studies which did not use this manipulation check may have introduced confounds to their results. Any significant effects found in this secondary analysis will not be considered except in comparison with the main analysis.

q23.value:
Participants who do not complete all 3 waves will be excluded from those analyses which require their participation in all waves.
Those participants who do not return for wave 2 will not be invited to participate in wave 3.

Participants will be paid minimum wage. We chose to limit our analysis to an age range of individuals for several reasons. The sample demographic on the prolific website is heavily skewed to this age range, so limiting it as such should not affect our sample size. As our sample size is fairly small, we decided that it was better to avoid the chance of the few particularly old or young participants being randomly assigned more to one condition than another and thus skewing our results. We deemed it worth the slight impact on the generalisability of our results. 

We selected only participants from the UK to protect against potential cultural differences.

We will also measure the time taken to leave the page of the persuasive text. Given the text is over 400 words long, if participants click away from the page in less than 20 seconds their data shall be excluded, with the assumption that they have not read the text.

Participants who do not complete all 3 waves will be excluded from those analyses which require their participation in all waves.

Given that several of our analyses are sensitive to outliers, we will be excluding participants who fall outside of 3 standard deviations from the mean.

There are several attention checks throughout the experiment. Participants who fail these will be excluded. 

Once data is collected, 2 researchers will conduct a double-blind analysis. The researchers will code each of the short stories, assigning them to either the “efficacy” or “control” condition. Any stories which either: researchers disagree on, or: the agreed upon label does not match their actual condition, will be excluded from the primary analysis. The full dataset will be used for a secondary analysis which aims to determine whether prior studies which did not use this manipulation check may have introduced confounds to their results. Any significant effects found in this secondary analysis will not be considered except in comparison with the main analysis.
registration_responses.q16.question: The independent variable will be random assignment to either the experimental or control condition. Participants in the experimental condition will be asked to write around 100 words about a time in the past when they felt they were in control. Participants in the control condition will be asked to write around 100 words about an important time in their past.
registration_responses.q17.question:
This study has 3 dependent variables.
The first dependent variable is intention to reduce consumption of beef and lamb in the future. This will be measured using a 1-7 Likert Scale.

The second dependent variable is meat consumption (specifically beef and lamb) in a period of 1 week. We will ask participants to report how many times they have eaten each type of meat, from a list of: Beef, Lamb, Poultry, Pork, Fish, Other.

A third dependent variable will be willingness to receive emails about pro-environmental topics. This will be operationalized using an optional sign up sheet within the questionnaire. 

We will also measure perceived behavioural control (PBC), Socioeconomic status (SES) and pro-environmental beliefs.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Our 2 SES questions will be averaged and then standardized (z-scored).

All PBC questions will be recoded to ensure that high responses equate to high PBC, and averaged in wave.

We will aggregate beef and lamb consumption.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use a one way ANOVA to investigate the impact of the experimental condition on pro-environmental intention.

In order to test our second hypothesis, a Mixed ANOVA will be used to compare the differences between the two groups at different time points. We will use the Mixed ANOVA to compare the consumption of beef and lamb at week 1 (before the intervention), with the consumption of beef and lamb at week 2 (after the intervention). 

In order to test hypothesis 3, we will use chi squared tests to compare the mean difference in willingness to receive information between the two conditions.

We will run a number of regressions in order to test hypotheses 4 and 5. In order to determine whether SES, environmental beliefs or PBC moderated the relationship between the efficacy manipulation and intention/behaviour, we will use 3 different statistical tests. We shall use a binomial logistic regression to investigate this hypothesis with our secondary dependent variable (willingness to receive information). We will use an ordinal logistic regression when investigating the relationship with intention, and we will use multiple regression to investigate the effect on our main dependent variable (beef and lamb consumption). Hierarchical linear regressions will be used to establish whether our predictor variables predict over each other (for example, whether an interaction between PBC and environmental beliefs predicts over environmental beliefs). We shall also run a mediated moderation analysis followed by a path analysis to attempt to determine the relationship between SES, environmental beliefs and PBC, and how each relate to intention and behaviour. We will investigate the interaction between SES and condition, Environmental beliefs and SES, Perceived behavioural control and SES, and Environmental beliefs and perceived behavioural control. These interaction effects are based on relationships discovered by past research, such as Eom, Kim and Sherman (2018).

In order to test our fifth hypothesis, we will also be measuring perceived behavioural control over the 3 waves of our study: First to ensure that our manipulation actually affects perceived behavioural control, and second to see whether any change in behaviour is linked to a similar change in behavioural control. We will use a one way repeated measures ANOVA to track the change in PBC over time in our two groups.

A secondary part of our analysis centres around a test of methodology. We will run one analysis using our entire dataset, and a second analysis using only data from participants who have correctly completed the writing task. This analysis will reveal whether the findings of previous studies which have not conducted this manipulation check may have been compromised.
To achieve this aim, 2 researchers will conduct a double-blind analysis of the passages. The researchers will code each of the short stories, assigning them to either the “efficacy” or “important” condition. Only those stories which both researchers agree are stories which show efficacy, and which were written by participants in the efficacy condition, will be included in the primary analysis as experimental participants (and vice versa for controls). By doing this, we also ensure that only those participants who properly experienced the experimental manipulation are included in the main analysis.

attributes.title: National and International Experiences on Knowledge Translation to  improve Maternal, Neonatal and Perinatal Care at Technical, Professional, and Traditional Leve. Systematic Review of Literature and Meta-analysis: Protocol

summary.value: El concepto de desarrollo sostenible surgió en la Comisión Brundtland, constituida por la Asamblea General de la ONU en 1983, que lo definió como el desarrollo que permite satisfacer las necesidades de las generaciones presentes sin comprometer las posibilidades de las del futuro de satisfacer sus propias necesidades, y buscaba atender tanto las demandas por una agenda de protección del medio ambiente, como las de asegurar el desarrollo de los países con menor nivel de desarrollo. Posteriormente, en el año 2000 se adoptaron los Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio (ODS), como una estrategia de colaboración para combatir la pobreza en sus múltiples dimensiones. Pese a que se reconocen sus avances en el ámbito de la salud, las disparidades dentro y entre los países fueron enmascaradas por el aparente logro de los objetivos planteados. En este marco, en el 2015 se planteó la Agenda 2030 como una apuesta política para el logro del desarrollo sostenible y en la cual se establecieron 17 objetivos, 169 metas y 232 indicadores.

registration_responses.summary: El concepto de desarrollo sostenible surgió en la Comisión Brundtland, constituida por la Asamblea General de la ONU en 1983, que lo definió como el desarrollo que permite satisfacer las necesidades de las generaciones presentes sin comprometer las posibilidades de las del futuro de satisfacer sus propias necesidades, y buscaba atender tanto las demandas por una agenda de protección del medio ambiente, como las de asegurar el desarrollo de los países con menor nivel de desarrollo. Posteriormente, en el año 2000 se adoptaron los Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio (ODS), como una estrategia de colaboración para combatir la pobreza en sus múltiples dimensiones. Pese a que se reconocen sus avances en el ámbito de la salud, las disparidades dentro y entre los países fueron enmascaradas por el aparente logro de los objetivos planteados. En este marco, en el 2015 se planteó la Agenda 2030 como una apuesta política para el logro del desarrollo sostenible y en la cual se establecieron 17 objetivos, 169 metas y 232 indicadores.

attributes.title: TETRIAS
attributes.description:
In 2018, the universities of applied sciences (UASs) in the Netherlands signed the Dutch code of conduct on research integrity (RI). By doing so, the UASs have committed themselves to taking care of an open and safe research culture, a proper management of research data, honest and open agreements on the research data, setting research ethics standards and advice, and to the training of their researchers. However, so far UASs themselves hardly offer any systematic training in the field of RI.
Our goal is to enable the UASs in The Netherlands to meet their obligation to provide their researchers access to a basic training course in the field of RI. To that goal we will systematically develop a blended training course that provides online information on integrity topics and offers researchers the opportunity to deepening important, and for their specific situation relevant topics through group-discussions and meetings with experts.
The training is to be tailored to the needs of the researchers in UASs. For that purpose, focus group discussions will be organised prior to designing the training. Topics to be discussed in the focus groups are: what makes a good UAS researcher; which norms of the Dutch Code of Conduct researchers do and do not recognise, and which needs for RI training do they identify? Based on this input learning objectives will be drawn up.
Secondary aim of the focus group discussions* is to pilot test several training methods that are already applied in RI training in other settings (i.e. the VIRT2UE training program). These methods will be embedded in the focus group discussion guide.
* Due to the measures against the spread of COVID-19, we will conduct interviews by telephone to replace the focus group discussions.

q1.value: Fenneke Blom, Rob van der Sande, Susan Berentsen

q2.value: The aim of this project is to develop training on research integrity for researchers at universities of applied sciences. We expect this to result in a blended learning training program, with online and offline components. The content will be depending on the expressed need by the target audience of the training. We hypothesize to learn from the target audience that the training course should focus on the development of competencies of researchers that contribute to RCR, such as: the knowledge of laws, regulations, guidelines and codes of conduct; the skills to identify the ethical dimensions of situations (ethical sensitivity); the skills to reflect on those dimensions (ethical reasoning); and the ability to develop defensible rationales for a choice of action in case of conflicting values.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Interviews
Literature study

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Semi-structured interviews by telephone using an interview guide with topics and suggested questions.
Interviewees will be recruited by members of the project's steering committee. Committee members are asked to recruit two researchers (a junior and a senior researcher) from their own university of applied sciences in research sectors assigned by the project team. From each sector a juniopr research and a senior researcher is being sought.

q11.value:
We plan to conduct 10 interviews in the first round, after which we will decide whether futher questions to the target audience should be asked and/or more data needs to be collected to reach data saturation. 
Depending on the situation with COVID-19 we will continue data collection by telephone interviews in case foucs group discussions are still not possible to conduct in a reasonable and responsible way.

q12.value: Two researchers (junior and senior) from each of the five sectors of research.

question.value: n/a

Topics to be addressed in the interviews are listed below. see for more details the interview guide.
- consent
- aims of the project
- experience so far with the topic of research integrity
- what is a 'good researcher', and how can you tell
- breaches of good research (cases, factors and prevention)
- Dutch Code of Conduct for Research Integrity
- Training on research integrity: what is needed?
n/a

q23.value: This concerns qualitative research, so many of the registration field do not fully match our type of research. We look forward to adapt the registration once a format for qualitative research is available.

subjects.text: Other Teacher Education and Professional Development

attributes.title: Personal similarity at the workplace
attributes.description: This project investigates the effects of perceived similarity on liking on work contests. We investigate the moderating effects of job desirability on this relationship.

q1.value: Jimena Ramirez-Marin, Adrian Barragan Diaz, Mario Pandelaere

q2.value:
1) Perceived similarity will increase liking
2) The effect of perceived similarity on liking will be moderated by job desirability. Similar others in undesirable jobs will be liked less than similar others in desirable jobs.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a factorial design and the factors are 2 similarity (high vs low) x 2 job positions (desirable and undesirable). It is a between subjects design. No counterbalancing is required. All participants will be randomly assigned to conditions.

q7.value: We use qualtrics and the software uses simple randomization for the blocks containing the manipulations.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: We will use the pilot study to calculate the effect size for our sample calculation.

question.value: We will use the platform Mechanical Turk to collect the data.

q11.value: The number of participants will be 252.

q12.value: We performed an a priori analysis using G*power. The parameters were t-test mean comparison for two independent groups. Effect size = .415, error probability = .05, power = .95 and allocation ratio = 1.

question.value: Please find a word version of all materials in the attached file

Perceived similarity
Liking candidate
Job desirability
We have one item indicators no no indices will be created.

We plan to conduct a t-test to check for effects of manipulation on our perceived similarity item. We will also conduct a regression analysis to test the indirect effects of job desirability on the relationship between similarity and liking.

q18.value: We plan to have a coding scheme for our manipulation variable with the following indicators high similarity=1 low similarity -1.

q19.value: We will be using one tailed test for the hypothesis testing.

q20.value: We will exclude outliers. outlier is a point which falls more than 1.5 times the interquartile range above the third quartile or below the first quartile.

q21.value: If this is system missing data, we will remove it from the sample.

q22.value: We do  not plan to conduct exploratory analysis as the dependent variables are only those necessary to test our hypothesis.

attributes.title: RWA and SDO and the COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description: Relationships between RWA, SDO, Conspiratorial Beliefs about COVID-19, and Helping Behaviors.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: RWA, SDO, Conspiracies, and Helping Behavior.

other.value:
The Study will be made live on Monday March 30th, and we will only collect data on March 30th.

We have one news exposure item for exploratory purposes. Please check all the news sources below that you have been exposed to in the past week:
a.	CNN
b.	Bloomberg
c.	Fox News
d.	The New Yorker
e.	Breitbart
f.	Yahoo News
g.	NPR
h.	Mother Jones
i.	MSNBC
j.	Slate
k.	BBC News
l.	Drudge Report
m.	PBS
n.	Huffington Post
o.	Wall Street Journal
p.	Al Jazeera America
q.	ABC News
r.	BuzzFeed
s.	CBS News
t.	Local newspaper
u.	NBC News
v.	Local TV
w.	USA TODAY
x.	Local Radio
y.	Google News
z.	Rush Limbaugh Show
aa.	The Blaze
bb.	The Economist
cc.	NY Times
dd.	Daily Kos
ee.	Washington Post
ff.	The Guardian
gg.	Vice News
hh.	Other

We will also collect the following demographics measures:
1. income
2. education level
3. age
4. gender

As a secondary analysis, we aim to see if the same hypothesized relationships hold when statistically controlling for these 4 demographics variables. 

We will also ask the extent to which participants are socially and economically conservative to correlate with all of our other measures in an exploratory fashion.

sample.value: 500 participants will be collected on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
1. We will correlate RWA and SDO with all DVs listed above.
2. We will compute mediation models with Hayes' PROCESS MACRO in SPSS to determine whether conspiratorial beliefs about the COVID-19 mediates the relationships between RWA/SDO and the other DVs listed above.

outliers.value: The study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value:
We will use the conspiratorial and xenophobic beliefs listed below. Each item will be rated on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree):

Xenophobia Items:
One of the best ways to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in the United States is to stop immigration into the United States. 
Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, America should close its borders to immigrants. 
I find it racist when people refer to coronavirus as “Chinese coronavirus” or “Wuhan disease.” (reverse-scored)
Immigrants are responsible for the spread of COVID-19 in America.

COVID-19 as a Biological Weapon Items:
COVID-19 was engineered by members of the Chinese government as a biological weapon.
COVID-19 was engineered by members the United States government as a biological weapon.

Comparison to Other Epidemics/Diseases Items: 
The current COVID-19 pandemic is already worse than the Ebola virus outbreak.
The current COVID-19 pandemic is already worse than the seasonal flu.
The current COVID-19 pandemic is already worse than the common cold.
The current COVID-19 pandemic is already worse than the H1N1 (swine flu) outbreak.
The COVID-19 death rate is higher than the seasonal flu death rate.

Conspiracy to Harm Donald Trump Items:
The COVID-19 pandemic is a conspiracy to harm President Donald Trump 
The COVID-19 pandemic is a scam to make President Donald Trump look bad 
The COVID-19 pandemic is a dishonest scheme to hurt President Donald Trump 
 
Media Reaction Items:
The mainstream news media are blowing the COVID-19 pandemic out of proportion.
The COVID-19 pandemic is worse than mainstream news media claim. (reverse-scored)
The mainstream news media are exaggerating the negative effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Public Reaction Items:
The general public in America is overreacting to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The general public in America is too hysterical about the COVID-19 pandemic.
The general public in America are exaggerating the negative impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic

Cure Beliefs Items:
There is already a cure for COVID-19
A cure already exists for COVID-19
There is no cure for COVID-19 yet (reverse-scored)

Note that the following sets of items will be averaged to form composites indexing the following: Xenophobia, Conspiracy to Harm Donald Trump, Media Reaction, Public Reaction, and Cure Beliefs, respectively. If any set of items fails to have adequate reliability (Cronbach's alpha below .65), we will investigate the items separately.

We also have two COVID-19 Help Items:
To what extent have you been practicing social distancing in the past month in response to the COVID-19 pandemic? (1 = not at all, 7 = all the time)
To what extent have you increased the number of times that you have washed your hands with soap and water in the past month in response to the COVID-19 pandemic? (1 = not at all, 7 = a lot)

hypothesis.value:
1. Do right wing authoritarianism (RWA) or social dominance orientation (SDO) predict conspiratorial and xenophobic beliefs related to COVID-19?
2. Do RWA or SDO predict helping behaviors in response to COVID-19 (i.e., social-distancing and hand-washing)?
3. Do conspiratorial or xenophobic beliefs about the COVID-19 pandemic mediate the relationship between RWA/SDO and helping behaviors in response to COVID-19?

1. Do right wing authoritarianism (RWA) or social dominance orientation (SDO) predict conspiratorial and xenophobic beliefs related to COVID-19?

attributes.title: The effects of epidural stimulation on individuals with spinal cord injury or disease and animal models of spinal cord injury: a scoping review.
attributes.description: A synthesis of the effects of epidural stimulation on individual with spinal cord injury or disease and animal models across several domains. These domains include pain, spasms, spasticity, bowl and bladder, cardiovascular and cardiometabolic systems, and upper and lower extremity function.

attributes.title: Mapping the Knowledge on Coping with Pancreatic Cancer
attributes.description: Conducting a scoping review to answer the question 'What is currently known about coping with pancreatic cancer?' to summarise and disseminate research findings in medicine and health sciences and to identify gaps in the current research literature.

q1.value: Mapping the Knowledge on Coping with Pancreatic Cancer: A Scoping Review

q2.value: Patrick Ristau, Wilfried Schnepp, Andreas Büscher

q3.value: Through there is no model on coping with pancreatic cancer, this scoping review is conducted to map the current knowledge on coping with pancreatic cancer to summarise and disseminate research findings in medicine and health sciences and to identify gaps in the current research literature.

q4.value: It is important that health professionals get a better understanding of what it feels like to go through pancreatic cancer. This tumour disease it differs from other tumour entities so that already known models of coping with specific cancer diseases are not simply transferrable to it.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping review based on the framework by Arksey and O'Malley and the JBI methodology is carried out in common literature databases (such as PubMed, CINAHL, and Cochrane Library).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The methodological approach is based on the framework provided by Arksey and O'Malley (2005).
As a first step, PubMed, CINAHL, and Cochrane Library will be searched. Titles, abstracts, and index terms of the hits retrieved will be analyzed regarding possible search terms.
As a second step, the databases from the first step and also Google Scholar, CAMbase, CareLit, CC Med, Scopus, and PsycARTICLES will be scanned with the keywords and index terms identified. Then, a title-abstract-screening is performed to remove articles that do not meet the pre-defined inclusion criteria. Afterwards, the remaining articles will be stored electronically in full text and evaluated in detail according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. 
As the third and last step, the reference lists of hits will be browsed for potential additional studies. The search will be limited to the reference lists of those articles that have been included in the scoping review.
The review will include quantitative and qualitative research as well as reviews of any kind published on coping in adults with pancreatic malignancies. Both English and German language journal articles will be included regardless of their year of publication. There will be no restrictions regarding therapy goals or strategies.
Publications without abstracts will be excluded. Furthermore, studies that focus on other pancreatic diseases like pancreatitis will be excluded. In addition, letters, discussion papers, websites etc. will not be considered.
n/a

The results compiled in the outlined scoping review will provide an overview of the state of research on coping with pancreatic cancer. The authors will prepare a narrative report summarizing the extracted data to the elaborated findings.
n/a

A scoping review is often used to map the concepts underlying a research area and the main sources and types of evidence and knowledge available. The authors will summarize the extracted data in a narrative report. A specific data extraction framework will be used for this purpose.

q25.value:
Arksey H, O'Malley L. Scoping studies: towards a methodological framework. International Journal of Social Research Methodology. 2005;8:19–32. doi:10.1080/1364557032000119616.
Peters MDJ, Godfrey C, McInerney P, Baldini Soares C, Khalil H, Parker D. Chapter 11: Scoping Reviews. In: Aromataris E, Munn Z, editors. Joanna Briggs Institute Reviewer's Manual; 2017.

attributes.title: Economic Evaluations to inform resource allocation for the prevention and management of Clostridioides difficile infections: A scoping review protocol
attributes.description: This scoping review aims to describe the characteristics of economic evaluations of interventions for the prevention and management of C. difficile infections

summary.value: This protocol registration summarizes the background, objective, and review methods (i.e., research questions, literature search strategy, inclusion and exclusion criteria, details of data extraction) for a planned scoping review.

registration_responses.summary: This protocol registration summarizes the background, objective, and review methods (i.e., research questions, literature search strategy, inclusion and exclusion criteria, details of data extraction) for a planned scoping review.
